org.orgName: United States District Court For The Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: In the Matter of the Application of CHAS. JACKSON for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

On reading and filing the complaint of Charles Jackson, and it appearing therefrom that the said Charles Jackson is unlawfully restrained of his liberty at the United States Immigration Detention Station in Seattle, King County, Washington, by Henry M. White, Commissioner of Labor of the United States, acting under the pretended authority of a warrant of deportation issued by the Secratary of Labor of the United States, wherein it is charged that the said complainant is an alien, and that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry into the united States, and that a hearing was held to inquire into the merits of said charge, and that a complete copy of the testimony taken at such hearing is in the possession of said Henry M. White, and ought to be produced on the hearing of said mattter in order that the court may have the best evidence available upon the issues tendered in the complaint herein,

Now, therefore, it is ordered that the clerk issue out of and under the seal of this court, a writ of Habeas Corpus directed to Henry M. White, Commissioner of Labor of the United States, stationed at Seattle, Washington, requiring that he produce the body of the complainant, Charles Jackson, in the above entitled court before me on the 18th day of November, 1918, at two o'clock in the afternoon, and then and there show cause if any, he has, why the said Charles jackson should be further restrained of his liberty, and that said writ further direct the said Henry M. White also then and there to produce properl authenticated under his seal, a copy of the testimony taken at the hearings held pursuant to the mandate of the warrant of arrest issued by the Secretary of Labor, pursuant to which the complainant, the said Charles Jackson, is restrained of his liberty by him, the said Henry M. White. and why a writ of Habeas Corpus should not ensue
